title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #1078: Minimum Degree for K_r in r-Partite Graphs**

**Setup:** r-partite graph with n vertices in each of r parts.

**Question:** If min degree ≥ (r - 3/2 - o(1))n, must G contain K_r?

**Answer:** YES (Haxell 2001)

**Sharp:** (r-1)n - ⌈sn/(2s-1)⌉ where s = ⌊r/2⌋ (Haxell-Szabó 2006)
mathContext: This connects minimum degree conditions to forcing complete subgraphs in multipartite graphs.

title: r-Partite Graph
content:
**RPartiteGraph:**

A structure with:
- r parts, each a Finset of size n
- Parts are disjoint and cover all vertices
- Edges only between different parts

**Key property:** No edges within a part (each part is independent).

title: Contains K_r
content:
**ContainsKr:**

The graph contains K_r = complete graph on r vertices, with exactly one vertex from each part.

Formally: ∃ f : Fin r → vertices such that:
- f(i) ∈ part i for all i
- f(i) and f(j) are adjacent for all i ≠ j

title: BES Conjecture
content:
**Bollobás-Erdős-Szemerédi Conjecture (1975):**

If min degree ≥ (r - 3/2)n - O(1), then G contains K_r.

**Key insight:** The threshold (r - 3/2) involves a half-integer, suggesting parity plays a role.

title: Haxell's Theorem (2001)
content:
**Haxell's Proof:**

The BES conjecture is TRUE.

**Method:** Used connections to list coloring (vertex coloring from lists).

**Significance:** Resolved a 25+ year old conjecture.

title: Sharp Threshold Formula
content:
**sharpThreshold (Haxell-Szabó 2006):**

(r-1)n - ⌈sn/(2s-1)⌉ where s = ⌊r/2⌋

**Meaning:**
- s = ⌊r/2⌋ captures parity of r
- Ceiling function gives exact discrete threshold
- Asymptotically ≈ (r - 3/2)n

title: Special Cases
content:
**Computing sharpThreshold for small r:**

- **r = 2:** Threshold ≈ 0 (any edge is K_2)
- **r = 3:** Threshold = n (need edges to both other parts)
- **r = 4:** Threshold = 3n - ⌈2n/3⌉

These match the (r - 3/2)n asymptotic up to O(1).

title: Independent Transversal
content:
**IsIndependentTransversal:**

A selection T = {t_1, ..., t_r} with one vertex from each part, such that no two selected vertices are adjacent.

**Connection:** K_r exists iff the complement has no independent transversal.

title: Why r - 3/2
content:
**Intuition for the Threshold:**

- Need edges to all r-1 other parts
- Naive threshold: (r-1)n
- Parity trick saves ~n/2 per part
- Net: (r-1)n - n/2 = (r - 3/2)n

The extremal construction uses subtle parity arguments.

title: Summary: SOLVED
content:
**Erdős Problem #1078:**

**STATUS:** SOLVED

**Conjecture:** min degree (r-3/2-o(1))n ⇒ K_r exists

**Proof:** Haxell (2001)

**Sharp:** (r-1)n - ⌈sn/(2s-1)⌉ (Haxell-Szabó 2006)

**Best Possible:** BES showed r-3/2 is tight

**Key Insight:** Parity and transversal theory are essential.
